results.title: Judge Dredd for Commodore 64/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Judge Dredd [computer game]. Judge Dredd is a single player action platformer. Players move Dredd to locations of crime as they appear on the sector map and select the crime they wish to pass judgement on. Once a crime has been selected, Dredd is dropped into a side scrolling platformer where both perps and civilians roam. Each crime is given an appropriate response level of Halt, Warn and Kill, though it is up to player discretion to change the response level. Depending on the response level is the action Dredd can perform, either shouting halt, firing warning shots or firing real bullets. Dredd can select a type of bullet from normal, armour piercing, incendiary, ricochet, high explosive and heat seeking.

results.title: Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: Melbourne House, Psion Software and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Hungry Horace for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Hungry Horace [computer game]. Hungry Horace is a top down single player arcade game similar to Pac Man. Players control Horace through a maze collecting flowers and guards lunches while avoiding capture by the park guards. Horace can ring alarms and frighten guards from the park. If Horace is caught three times, he is thrown out of the park and the game ends.

results.title: Horace Goes Skiing for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: William Tang, Melbourne House, Psion Software and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Horace Goes Skiing [computer game]. Horace Goes Skiing is a single player game with multiple genres. The first is similar to Frogger, where players begin with $40 and guide Horace across a busy road to the ski lodge. Getting hit by a vehicle costs Horace $10 in ambulance fees. Once Horace makes it to the lodge and hires skiis, it becomes a ski game where players slalom between flags and avoid trees. Colliding with a tree will send Horace back to the start of the game. When Horace runs out of money, the game ends.

Once Horace makes it to the lodge and hires skiis, it becomes a ski game where players slalom between flags and avoid trees. Colliding with a tree will send Horace back to the start of the game. When Horace runs out of money, the game ends.

results.title: H.U.R.G. for ZX Spectrum 48K
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer program. Cassette, manual, cardboard cassette case and plastic cassette tray.
results.brief_description:
“H.U.R.G., High-Level User-Friendly Real-Time Games Designer”, is a program that enables you to create games. It is a menu driven utility designed to assist in creating games for the ZX Spectrum 48K and can be used by those with little or no knowledge of programming. For example, by using the ‘Edit Game’ menu option, the player can select actions such as creating a title page or specifying playing conditions via sub-menus. Utilities like these opened the possibilities for using home computers, by making programming accessible to anyone who was interested. Games created with “H.U.R.G.” are not stand-alone; they still require the engine to run.

“H.U.R.G.” came with three demo games that were created within the engine: ‘Manic Koala’, ‘Egg Pack’ and ‘Ms. Hortense’. Melbourne House ran competitions to encourage people to use “H.U.R.G.” in games design, with cash prizes for the best games created on the software.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/h-u-r-g-high-level-user-friendly-real-time-game-designer/

Last accessed: 5/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software. Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.

results.title: Exploding Fist +  for ZX Spectrum 48/128/+2
results.creator_credit: Firebird Software, Telecomsoft and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Exploding Fist + [computer game]. Exploding Fist + is a side view beat ‘em up for up to three players. Players fight increasingly tougher opponents to rank as 10th Dan with a wide variety of karate kicks, punches, cartwheels and blocks. Once players have attained the rank of 10th Dan, they must then defend their title against more opponents. Players either score eight points or have the most before the bout ends. Points are scored by striking a fighter. The two highest scoring fighters progress to the next bout. If there is a tie, a replay bout will take place. After every two bouts, surviving players can play a bonus game where they throw ninja stars at demons hiding in a dark alley for additional points.

results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.

results.title: Demon Stalkers for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Electronic Arts and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, code wheel, warranty card & manual (paper booklet) in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forte Studios for Commodore 64 and 128, published in 1987 by Electronic Arts.
